questions.prompt: What does a differential amplifier amplify?
questions.explanation: A differential amplifier amplifies Vo = AD(Vi2 - Vi1). It responds to the DIFFERENCE between inputs, rejecting signals common to both.
CMRR = Common Mode Rejection Ratio = AD/Acm. It measures how well the amplifier rejects signals common to both inputs (like noise).

questions.prompt: For an ideal differential amplifier, what is the common-mode gain?
questions.explanation: An ideal diff amp has Acm = 0, meaning it completely rejects common-mode signals. This gives CMRR = ∞.

questions.prompt: If R1 = R3 = 2.2kΩ and R2 = R4 = 39kΩ, what is the differential gain?
options: All of the above are equivalent
questions.correctAnswer: All of the above are equivalent
questions.explanation: AD = R2/R1 = 39/2.2 = 17.73. Note this is the same as the inverting amp gain magnitude (but the diff amp amplifies the difference).

questions.prompt: What resistor condition is required for ideal differential amplifier operation?
questions.explanation: For perfect common-mode rejection, the resistor ratios must be matched: R2/R1 = R4/R3. Any mismatch creates finite Acm.

questions.prompt: If AD = 100 and Acm = 0.01, what is CMRR?
questions.explanation: CMRR = AD/Acm = 100/0.01 = 10,000. This is a good CMRR, meaning common-mode signals are rejected 10,000 times more than they're amplified.

questions.prompt: What is 60 dB expressed as a linear ratio?
questions.explanation: dB_value = 20log₁₀(ratio). So 60 = 20log₁₀(ratio), meaning log₁₀(ratio) = 3, therefore ratio = 10³ = 1000.

questions.prompt: When both inputs receive the same 1V signal, the ideal differential amplifier output is:
questions.explanation: If Vi1 = Vi2 = 1V, then Vd = Vi2 - Vi1 = 0. Therefore Vo = AD × 0 = 0. Common-mode signals are rejected!

questions.prompt: The 741 op-amp has CMRR ≈ 70 dB. As a linear ratio, this is approximately:
Why might a measured CMRR be lower than the op-amp's datasheet value?
questions.explanation: Standard 5% resistors have significant tolerance that causes R2/R1 to differ from R4/R3. This mismatch creates finite Acm, lowering CMRR.
